categories.summary: The customer expresses concern over a drastic change in reported numbers after switching from imurica to Brandwatch. They are unsure if the formula changes are the cause and were not informed of these changes. They also mention missing pieces of coverage in the Excel sheet and daily clippings, leading to a lack of trust in the platform's accuracy and increased manual work for their team.

The customer emphasizes the importance of AVE as a measurement within their business and expresses disappointment that the formula changed without notification. They are concerned about the significant drop in AVE numbers post-platform switch, which impacts their reporting and creates an awkward position internally. They also express concern that they are paying a lot of money for a service that is not being double-checked.

The customer expresses disappointment and a lack of trust due to the unannounced changes in the AVE formula and the perception that imurica's numbers were outdated. They feel they were failed on two counts: not being informed of the formula update and the outdated nature of the previous data. This has led to a loss of confidence in the accuracy of the reports and increased workload for their team.

The customer mentions involving Rebecca, Palm, and the team in discussions. They report AVE weekly to business units and need to build a case for future changes. They need to buy time to have internal conversations. They need to report consistently to the wider business. They need to do change management with stakeholders. They are tight on resources and need to trust the figures they are reporting.

The customer needs to resolve questions quickly. They need to make the current system work and then build a case for the future. They have a short-term issue to fix quickly and want the older figures back on the report this Friday.
The customer is looking for a solution that will solve their short term needs.

summary.text: This transcript captures a sales meeting between Rebecca Taylor and Daniel Wilson from imurica (the seller side) and Laura and Emma from M&S (the buyer side), focusing on M&S's concerns about discrepancies in AVE (Advertising Value Equivalency) measurements following a platform transition from decision to Brandwatch. imurica proposed to address the accuracy of content by reviewing automated search terms and acknowledged the need for better communication regarding formula changes. M&S expressed strong reliance on AVE for reporting and disappointment over the unannounced formula changes, highlighting a significant drop in reported AVE figures. M&S requested imurica revert to a measurement approach similar to the older system to maintain reporting consistency in the short term, while indicating willingness to discuss broader measurement metrics in the future. imurica agreed to revert to the older numbers for this Friday's report and will provide an update early next week on the audit of search strings to address missing coverage.

items.original_text: Daniel Wilson: Share collateral and content on why AVE shouldn't be used, for when the client is ready to discuss it with their leadership.
Daniel Wilson: The team to conduct a full review of automated search terms over the next week to improve content accuracy to at least 80-90%.
Daniel Wilson: Find out the exact thresholds for word count to determine the size of print articles, especially for image-heavy pieces.
Daniel Wilson: Provide Laura with the formula used for online valuation.
Daniel Wilson: Investigate and resolve the issue of missing coverage, ensuring all pieces in the daily clippings are included in the reports.
Daniel Wilson: revert back to similar to the older figures for the report this Friday.
Rebecca Taylor: Resend the email invitation for a collaborative session with all business units and review the agenda.
Daniel Wilson: Follow up with Laura and Emma early next week regarding the audit of search strings and the remedy for missing content.

On NextGen C3, and I didn't manage the product development there, so I'm kind of, um,
Looking into a bit of what other teams have done in the past, they seem to have used ad rates which are based on the amount that you would pay if you go to the specific website.
So if you go to the Daily Mail and say we want to advertise with the Daily Mail, how much is it going to cost us?
Now in reality with online advertising that is generally not how people would pay for adverts on websites like you spend all day procuring adverts if you're going to specific websites.
You go to a demand side provider and you say these are the types of audiences or people we want to reach.
This is how many people we would ideally like to reach and you would pay them for that.
And actually the difference between those is quite stark.
So if you go to the Daily Mail, they would probably charge you 20 to 25 pounds per maybe 1000 people that you're reaching.
Whereas if you go to a demand side provider, they would charge you 750 to 10 pounds to reach those types of people.
And they would advertise on those same like national newspapers and websites.
So, like, you can, Take slightly different methodologies and get to numbers that are correct.
They're not incorrect.
It's just you're kind of treating how you're trying to replicate advertising in different ways because there are different ways in which you can do it.
